function.name: submission_eval
function.description: This function is used to evaluate the public submission to the consultation. Each parameter property is a question that you must respond to after carefully reading the description.

substantive_submission.description: Does the submission provide a substantive response to the consultation (True or False)? Substantive submissions are those that provide a detailed or well-reasoned response to the consultation. Screenshots of memes or other pre-existing content are not considered substantive. Submissions relying on conspiracy theories are not considered substantive. A submission expressing a purely personal opinion without any supporting argument is not considered substantive. Consider the supplementary materials and determine if the submission substantively answers the issues, concerns and questions raised in the consultation.

responder_category.description: One aspect of the research is looking at how different categories of responders respond to the consultation. Based on the response (especially the name of the responder - e.g. if it is a company or group), please select the category that best describes the responder. Options are: 1. Individual, 2. Political (e.g. politician or political part), 3. Digital Platform (e.g. Meta, Microsoft, Google, etc.), 4. Civil Society (e.g. NGO, advocacy group, etc.), 5. Academic, 6. News (e.g. a news company such as News Corp, ABC or Nine News, or an industry association representing news organisations such as Australian Press Council, Commercial Radio Australia or FreeTV), 7. Government (e.g. government agencies such as the Victorian Electoral Commission or Australian Human Rights Commission), 8. Industry (An industry body that does not neatly fit within the predefined categories (e.g. while Commercial Radio Australia represents news broadcasters and as such fits within News, an industry body such as Communications Alliance, which represents communications providers such as telcos and broadband companies would fit here)), 9. Other (please specify). Only return the category that best describes the responder. E.g. for a submission from the UTS Centre for Media Transition, you would return: 'Academic'.

support.description: Considering the whole of the submission, does the submission support, oppose, provide qualified support, or have a neutral stance towards the proposed laws? Ensure you truly understand the submission's position, considering the whole document. Look for express statements expressing support or opposition. If no express statements are present, weigh up the arguments against and arguments in favour of the Bill and specific aspects of the proposed changes. Some confusion may arise when the submission states it supports another submission, but this does not mean the submission supports the proposed changes. In these circumstances, if you are unsure (i.e. the submission is not clear and you do not have access to the submission being referred to), respond with 'unsure'. Return only one of the following options: 'support', ‘qualified support’, 'oppose', 'neutral', 'unsure'.

motivations.description: List the top 3 motivations or concerns underpinning the submission's viewpoint. Keep each motivation general and brief (under five words). The most significant motivation or concern should be the first item in the array, followed by the second most important and then the third. If there are only one or two key motivations in the submission, return only these one or two.

regulation.description:
Does this submission make any comment as to the preferred form of regulation? For example, does the submission comment on the practicality, feasibility or merits of self-regulation, co-regulation or direct/government regulation? This question is only interested in specific comments from the submission on the FORM OF REGULATION and NOT whether or not the issue should be regulated. It is also not interested in the submission's view as to what the impacts of regulation may be. We are also not interested in the submission's view of the impacts that regulation, in general, will have. WE ARE ONLY interested in specific comments as to the form of regulation (e.g. self-regulation, co-regulation, direct/government regulation). If the submission makes explicit comments as to the preferred form of regulation, please return what the preferred form is. The options are: 1. Self-regulation
2. Co-regulation
3. Government/direct regulation
4. No regulation. If no comment on this issue, return 'No comment'. To help you understand the meanings of the different forms of regulation for this task, here is an overview of each:

**Self-regulation**

Self-regulation is generally characterised by industry-formulated rules and codes of conduct, with industry solely responsible for enforcement.
For example, the content of advertising is subject to a self-regulatory system created by the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA) in 1998. The AANA established a Code of Ethics. The related organisation Ad Standards operates a community panel that hear complaints regarding advertising content. Similarly, the Australian Press Council (APC) administers a self-regulatory scheme for print and online news. APC formulates principles and standards and takes complaints from the public, which are heard by adjudication panels.
The ‘classification’ of audio material is also self-regulated under the Recorded Music Labelling Code of Practice. There is no legislation, and individual record companies are responsible for labelling recordings under a code that outlines labelling provisions and establishes a complaints handling mechanism.

---

**Co-regulation**

Co-regulation typically refers to situations where industry develops and administers its own arrangements, but government provides legislative backing to enable the arrangements to be enforced.
Regulation of radio and television content is co-regulatory. Various industry groups have developed codes under Part 9 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (Cth). Most aspects of program content are governed by these codes, which include the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice and the Commercial Radio Australia Code of Practice and Guidelines. Once implemented, the ACMA monitors these codes and deals with unresolved complaints made under them. A similar scheme applies to telecommunications codes developed under Part 6 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 (Cth), such as the Telecommunications Consumer Protections Code.

---

**Direct/government regulation**

Direct government regulation comprises primary and subordinate legislation as well as rules developed by a government regulator. It is the most commonly used form of regulation. Examples of direct government regulation are: industry standards developed under Part 6 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 (Cth); programs standards developed under Part 9 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (Cth); the Broadcasting Services (Events) Notice 2023; the Online Safety (Basic Online Safety Expectations) Determination 2022; Guidelines for the Classification of Films 2012.

---

**No regulation**

No regulation is where there is no form of self-regulation, co-regulation or direction/government regulation. It includes situations where a company develops terms of use, community guidelines or some other form of rule that apply only to itself. We refer to this last type of arrangement as ‘governance’, but for this exercise, it can be classified as ‘no regulation’.

regulator_trust.description:
Does the submission express trust or scepticism towards the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA)'s ability to impartially and effectively use the new powers? To help answer this question, you may consider direct statements as to ACMA’s role in using the proposed powers, or you may infer a position, such as lack of trust, if the submission suggests or asks for practices, procedures or other methods for improving accountability and oversight. Please only return a position if the submission provides express statements as to the ability of the ACMA to effectively use the new powers or any express suggestions for ensuring accountability and oversight of the ACMA exercising its power. If there is no comment on this aspect, return 'No comment'. Your response options are:
1. Trust
2. Scepticism
3. No comment

definitions.description: Does the submitter provide any comments on the definitions of 'misinformation', 'disinformation' or 'serious harm'? Return a list containing which of these definitions the submission makes an explicit comment on the definition of. Only consider specific comments on the definitions of 'misinformation', 'disinformation' and 'serious harm'. For example, if the submission comments on the definitions of 'disinformation' and 'serious harm', you would return ['disinformation', 'serious harm']. If the submitter makes no comment on the definitions of these specific terms, return an empty array.
